6/10. This game is simply sloppy placed together in Unity, and is just not completed. I will admit I had fun playing this game, but the developers took many lazy shortcuts and published a half-finished alpha demo  Out of 10:  Gameplay - 7.5 Environment - 3 Level design - 2  Animation - 8 Art/Design - 2  Code/Optimization- 5  Gameplay is fairly fun, and the designer definitely had a cool idea going with the blocky environment, but this was just poorly executed. Many models in the game just don't match the art style, such as the grey tunnels. The font and GUI was poorly done. Lots of little things such as the FX when your bullet hits an enemy, you can see the borders of the png image they used. I could go on with endlessly listing little things this game needs, but you should really just buy it for yourself, since the game is only 20 cents. I would rate this negative, but I cannot complain since this game is practically free.  If you are a Game developer: Buy this game, and take note of everything that was sloppily done, and use them as a bad example for making your own game.

Decent but oft frustrating game where you run around pixelated platforms and hallways smacking down bit alien zombies with baseball bats, guns (and actually that is all I have used lol). It features simple k/m controls (WASD, Space, and M1/M2). It's really that basic. However, as you advance, the platforms tend to fall away behind you, so strategic retreats become quite limited without you falling to your death. It uses a basic point health system...you have 100, the creatures tend to have more. The game actually looks pretty cool, and the gameplay such as it is works perfectly. I have encountered no bugs or the like. So, while there isnt a whole lot to this game, it is a nice distraction and for the sub twenty cent price point it often features (with trading cards that allow you to make back your investment), this is a title I expect to see in pretty much every Steam Library.  This is a 6 out of 10 for me, but for the trading card budget titles, this is actually one of the better ones out there.

This game is ok, not perfect, not horrible just ok. The last few levels are really REALLY frustrating with the scaling of difficulty being off. I believe the fifth level to be harder than the sixth.   Controls are pretty good, I am able to freely control my character wherever I need to except you can't manipulate your jumps in air so if you make a bad jump, you can't correct yourself and it's back to the begining of the stage with you.  The levels are ok but some are panfully long and if you mess up at the very end, you have to start all the way at the beginning of the stage except for the last stage which is broken up into segments. If there were checkpoints in the stages, I wouldn't be so upset about dying over and over to something over and over again. Also when the enemies die, they leave segments of their body lying around. THIS can lead you to get stuck and take unintended hits from other enemies which can kill you and force you to start the stage. This is highly apparent in Test 8 where you can't jump over any of their body segments and when there's ten plus enemies on your butt, then it gets really frustrating when there's nothing you can do to prevent yourself from dying. Again, checkpoints would be great for the long stages. Another additon that would make the game better would be a sprint option.   Your movement speed is kind of on the slow side and for some reason, when you look up or look down, your movement speed is decreased. Why is this I would never know but it's stange and can lead to you getting swarmed by enemies because you can't move fast enough to get away from them. If there was a sprint button, then you could get away from swarms and feel safer but also risk running into obstacles that could instantly kill you as the risk vs. reward option.  Although some of the stages are really long, the game itself is really short. I beat all the stages in less than two hours and that's with Alt tabbing out of the game to check some other things while the game was running. While dying over and over again can be frustrating, what isn't frustrating is the soundtrack. The soundtrack is really good on the ears and can go well with what is being thrown at you in the stages. Beating the game gives you the sound test so you can listen to all the songs at your leasure.  For the price (under one dollar at the time of this review) I believe you're getting your money's worth. The game is harmless and can be fun but at the same time really frustrating. The game is worth it in my opinion because it's really cheap and you're getting a decent, although somewhat frustrating, experience in the long run. If anything it's worth it for the soundtrack alone.  Pros: Smooth control  Awesome music Cons: Frustrating enemy design  No checkpoints for really long stages  Short (Only nine levels)  Score: 3/5 Bare in mind you get what you pay for.

I was going through a rough time in my life. My parents were fighting constantly, I had no friends, and everyone I met hated me because I was fat. I needed something to prevent me from suicide. I could not find anything I really liked. I tried buying toys, but the store clerks always prevented me from buying anything because I was overweight. I tried making a vlog on YouTube about my troubles, but I was banned from youtube for supposedly impersonating Gabriel Iglesias. Google fined me all of my money until I only had $1.10 left.  The only things I had were things necessary for my survival. I was fed a potato every other day and also given water in a shot glass. Sometimes I forced myself to use the water as a way to bath instead of drinking it. I was locked in my room every day cuz my parents were busy fighting about which console to play on. Well, not entirely.  I had this netbook, one my parents got me for my birthday when I was 12. I used it for school, mostly, until now. I was also lucky enough to have a charger, and all the stuff you need to use the netbook. I decided, maybe give video games a try. No one would judge me there. I was unable to play the f2p games because A. They took too much storage and B. I would be banned whenever I joined a multiplayer game. I remembered the $1.10 I had left.  I knew I had to find something that gave me a reason to live. I looked through the steam store. Jesus almost nothing was $1.10! I was about to give up and just end my life when I found this game. Dead Bits . 99 cents, without 10% tax. It took up all the space on my netbook. After waiting for it to download, I opened up the game. Upon opening it up there was a well made launcher with many options. Once I opened up the actual game, I heard a sweet soundtrack, and saw some badass looking aliens and a cool human. Was this what I needed to continue living?  It was. I am proud to say Dead Bits saved my life. The characters were deep, had personality, and I was able to connect with them. The story was unique, suspenseful, and I shed multiple tears. The graphics were revolutionary, and the soundtrack was the first good thing I had heard in awhile. Dead Bits is an arcade FPS where you are apparently trying to gain your freedom by shooting things while walking backwards in between bouts of pointless platforming.   The intro level seems fine enough. Here's a gun, shoot those guys, watch them explode in a mess of cubes. Ok, this could be fun to mess around with. That feeling quickly fades once you start going through the monotony of the following levels. Enemies essentially consist of kamikaze monsters that run straight at you with reckless abandon. They swing wildly and miss as you circle strafe around them, but the game throws a red puff on your screen indicating you've been hit anyway. That leaves the strategy to walking backwards and killing the enemies as they filter toward you. But wait just one second, because some levels make the ground behind you magically disappear causing you to back into your death.    And death is so much fun. There are no checkpoints and every death kicks you back to the level select screen, because who doesn't want to reselect and reload the same level constantly? Of course, if you like reselecting and reloading the same level you are going to love this...platforming! Very few games do first person platforming well, and this is clearly not one of them. One section has you jump from disorienting spinning cube to disorienting spinning cube. Fun times. There are also moving platforms that for some reason, even when you are standing on them, don't move you. So you have to actually walk with the platform as it moves toward your destination.  The gunplay in this is also rather poor. The weapons are bland and boring and pack no punch. The smg sounds more like a typewriter than a firearm. Occasionally a kill will trigger a slo-mo moment. Unforunately, it's not the kind like Killing Floor that allows you to pull off a couple quick headshots, but the kind where everything just slows down around you for a couple seconds and then you carry on. The melee weapon is a frustrating tool you are forced to use due in part to poor hit detection using it, and the aforementioned poor hit detection when enemies swipe at you. Your best bet is to creep toward enemies slowly and stopping as soon as you pull one, since enemies only start their kamikaze attack once you reach a certain distance threshold. But by creep I don't mean use the crouch button. It's there and entirely pointless.  The concept of the game seems decent on the cover, but the execution leaves much to be desired and I wouldn't recommend it. If you want to walk backwards and shoot things play Serious Sam.

Honestly, I'd give this game a meh or a sideways thumb, but I honestly think it falls a little more under the thumbs down catagory rather than the thumbs up catagory. This game is more of a rage game than a happy, fun, shoot-em-up kid game. Even though you can tell this is definitely centered towards kids, this really isn't as fun as you'd think it is. You can tell it's towards kids because 1. Dubstep (that's it's ONLY soundtrack) 2. Simple, blocky textures 3. It's an FPS recreation of Minecraft.    Gameplay  It's exactly as you'd think- an FPS version of Minecraft. Nothing against the developers, but this type of gameplay is getting stale. I'm honestly surprised there weren't any COD weapons put in this game, considering how cliche it is.   Story  The story isn't really that original and is very forgetful. You start the game where your protagonist is sitting on his porch and is abducted by aliens and is forced to do these tasks to earn his freedom again. So basically, he just enslaved him. I say it's forgetful because damn, I really forgot I was captured by aliens while fighting off these Ice enemies shooting gigantic snow balls at me. True story, it's in level 5.    Gameplay Mechanics   The mechanics aren't exactly great in this game either. The developers chose not to go with checkpoints- which I think is a stupid idea. Without checkpoints, you are forced to restart the entire level if you die and quite frankly, dying is pretty common. Lots of the times, I'll get really far into the mission and then accidently fall off the edge of the platform I'm walking on and die, forcing me to restart the entire mission. This brings me to my next topic- enemies and how ♥♥♥♥ing overpowered they are.   Enemy Mechanics  No matter which enemy you are fighting, 1 hit will always take away 12 HP and you only have 100 HP. The enemy AI is programmed to kill you with no cost whatsoever, and so your enemies will hunt you down until they kill you or you kill them.  Killing enemies aren't hard at all , but when they stack up and you're against 3 or 4 enemies at once, they can kill you within  seconds .    Frame Rates  Finally, something good I can talk about. Frame rates are very smooth and do not drop below 50 FPS. This makes things a lot smoother and more easy to play.    Conclusion  Overall, I didn't have much fun with this game. It'd be a LOT better if they fixed jumping lengths (because on level 5, I died so many times just trying to get from spawn up to the giant ice enemy), added in multiplayer (both online and local), fixed enemy damage values, and maybe changed their gameplay a bit. I hate to bash on these developers because their game isn't really that bad, they just need some fine tuning before I'd call it a full retail game. 5/10

The idea behind Dead Bits is pretty attractive -- it's supposed to be a short and simple arcade style game where you run through a knock-off of the Portal Test Chamber.  However, it's clear that the implementation falls short of the idea. I would have been totally fine with a short, simple and not particularly inventive game, as long as it played reasonably smoothly.  Dead Bits does not play smoothly, and most of the 'challenges' felt rather unreasonable. Everything you encounter smacks of unpolished, slapped-together amateur work. I'm not talking about the low-res models or the art style; I'm talking about things like the giant cube hitboxes which don't fit the models at all, or the obnoxious visual effects which obscure the path ahead.  The game is supposed to be a platformer at heart, but the level design is frustrating and seemingly pointless. Everyting is designed to rush the player into moving ahead without looking; but the frequent holes in platforms and enemy-clogged chokepoints make it impossible to just race through in time to the music. Instead, you're forced to take every section slowly and methodically, memorising the safe path and the enemy locations.  There is nothing which saves this game, nothing which creates a hidden bit of fun to explore. It could have been an enjoyable game if only the creator had spent more effort on making sure that the levels were layed out better, that the enemies were in interesting locations and not just clogging the narrow parts of the track, and that the weapons available actually fit the challenges ahead. The effects and music show that the creator did put time into this game, and I don't want to simply disparge someone's work. However, as a game it simply doesn't deliver -- the gameplay is constantly interrupted by failings in the design and execution of the game idea.   I can't reccomend this game to play.
